TopicTitle: The Criteria for a Space Plane

Articles.Content:
I built an Aircraft and it can get to an Altitude of 43,000 but not able to achieve orbit, my question, would this still be considered a Space Plane?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-21T01:08:51Z" title="07/21/2015 01:08  AM" data-short="8 yr">July 21, 2015</time> by castille7**
  
Question Answered

In the Real World, there is no clear and precise end to Earth's atmosphere, so the definition for "space" is what everybody agrees on - generally the [Kármán line.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%A1rm%C3%A1n_line)

In KSP, there is a clear and precise end to Kerbin's atmoshere, namely 70 kilometres altitude, where the physics engine stops applying atmospheric effects.

So, as far as I'm concerned, in order for it to be a "space" plane, it needs to reach space, and thus needs to be able to achieve an apoapsis of at least 70 km. Note that that's not "orbit", which would make the craft much more useful in a working space program, and is probably what people think of when they first think "space plane".

Wonderful! thank you, I will keep working on it, these space planes are very challenging for sure!

Well, getting to space with a plane isn't too hard - it can be done with [minimal tech](http://i.imgur.com/Gbm3Eyn.png) too. What generally considered challenging are SSTO planes (as in 'single stage to orbit'). Taking a considerable payload too is indeed pretty hard (and enjoyable), so as landing back on the KSC runway. The [K-Prize](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/11214-The-K-Prize-100-reusable-spaceplane-to-orbit-and-back) is one of the most popular challenges.

Also, if you make a half-working SSTO and ask for help here, expect at least two pages of replies. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
